subject: Re: [junit] Instantiated TestCase won't run tests
msgSnippet: ... It would be best to start with Kent Beck s original paper, Smalltalk Testing with Patterns . It gives you some insight into the intent and design of JUnit
messageBody:
junityahoo@... wrote:
>
>
> > But can you understand why what you wrote could have come across that
> > way? It was pretty clear to me.
>
> E-mail can cause a lot of misunderstandings, especially when one
> projects their
> own assumptions into what they are reading.

...and we all do.

> That is understandable. But if you could point me to these pages then I
> would
> voraciously consume them. I have of course read all the attached
> documentation
> that comes with JUnit, and I have been trying to make use of the
> JUnit-Addons
> package.

It would be best to start with Kent Beck's original paper, "Smalltalk
Testing with Patterns". It gives you some insight into the intent and
design of JUnit (based on SUnit). Google will help you find it.

> Sure, but it is also enervating when you are told to give it up when you
> know
> that there is more to the story.

If we'd been able to chat over beer, I'd have been happy to go on....

> I believe that I have found my own answer. At least here are my
> thoughts at the
> moment. Data driven testing in the way that I am trying to do it is not
> easily
> supported in JUnit. There is likely a reason for this, since a lot of
> thought
> has gone into producing JUnit. I now believe that my approach is not in
> keeping
> with JUnit. Since I am running the actual metadata from the application
> through
> the test, I am doing more of a data driven functional type of testing. A
> solution that appears more consistent with JUnit and unit testing in general
> seems to be to make some mock metadata classes that are specially
> designed to
> exercise my code in the test. This way my test is not dependent on any
> production code rather than the actual class that it is testing, and I
> am not
> trying to dynamically find all the production code and iterate through
> it all.
> Instead I am looking to carefully engineer my own metadata to exercise
> my tests.
> To implement this I basically wrote an abstract test class, and then made
> specific subclasses that are each mainly concerned with building
> specific mock
> data. It is okay that this data is hardcoded rather than dynamic
> because I am
> looking to exercise the code by carefully building my own data rather than
> running through all data that currently exists in the application. I was
> basically being lazy by using data that already existed and not crafting
> my own.

"Lazy" might be harsh, but I'm with you.

> But running actual production data does seem useful at least a few times
> when
> testing your own tests, just because there is some potential in catering
> to your
> own tests when writing your own data as well. Does that part make
> sense? This
> is the only thing that feels strange about my current ideas. Am I on
> the right
> track?

Yes; it's just a question of which tools, and for this kind of
end-to-end testing, I recommend Fit/FitNesse, especially when it's
heavily data-driven, by which I mean the same algorithm and 100 sets of
input/expected output. The Fit ColumnFixture is built for that purpose.
